subject: Quickscript for American English (erratta)
msgSnippet: I just realized I made a mis-notation in my original post.  I intended to say that 32, 33 and 34 were the letters in question. To distill my question, then, in
messageBody:
I just realized I made a mis-notation in my original post. I intended
to say that 32, 33 and 34 were the letters in question.

To distill my question, then, in light of this new information: which
of the three (32,33,34) is useless to a standard American English
speaker? I have noticed that 32 is generally preferred for the "ah"
sound in "father" "caught" "cot", etc (as they are all one sound to
many Americans). I have also noticed, however, that Mr. Read
specified 33 as the "o" in "OR". This is a distinctly different vowel
insofar as I have heard it pronounced in American English, and it lies
as a glottal somewhere between 36 and 38. Does this mean that 34 is
the only vowel symbol to be altogether unused by American speakers, or
is there some usage of it that I am unaware of?

Are the three generally combined as 32 for Americans?

-Andy

I just realized I made a mis-notation in my original post.  I intended
to say that 32, 33 and 34 were the letters in question.

To distill my question, then, in light of this new information:  which
of the three (32,33,34) is useless to a standard American English
speaker?  I have noticed that 32 is generally preferred for the "ah"
sound in "father" "caught" "cot", etc (as they are all one sound to
many Americans).  I have also noticed, however, that Mr. Read
specified 33 as the "o" in "OR".  This is a distinctly different vowel
insofar as I have heard it pronounced in American English, and it lies
as a glottal somewhere between 36 and 38.  Does this mean that 34 is
the only vowel symbol to be altogether unused by American speakers, or
is there some usage of it that I am unaware of?

Are the three generally combined as 32 for Americans?

-Andy
